title: In Gundy v. United States, will the Supreme Court rule that Congress' delegation of authority to the attorney general in the federal Sex Offender Registration and Notification Act (SORNA) violates the nondelegation doctrine?
preds: oops just realized this question is closing June 28 and decision expected July 2019
Court composition combined with facts of retroactive discretion without boundaries makes this a good vehicle for proving the continued existence of non-delegation doctrine with relatively low impact.

Updating and adjusting upward from 12% to 85% based on the following: 
Becket foundation says a decision is expected in July 2019
https://www.becketlaw.org/case/gundy-v-united-states/
several amicus briefs have been supporting to affirm a decision on this question
fantasy scotus predicts the decision will affirm

the only reason it seems this decision would not affirm is if a decision is not reached.
Historically generous view of delegation of legislation powers
Unlikely decision based on arguments from appeals court
SCOTUS hasn’t made a whole lot of inroads into decreasing Congress’ gradual delegation of power to the executive branch, and I’m not convinced that they will do so on behalf of this appellant.

I don't think the Supreme Court will want to stunt overreach and broad interpretation it enjoys, not to mention that this case involves a sex offender, and in the metoo movement letting a sex offender be victorious over anything would be bad PR.
one can only hope... the attorney general does NOT need more power
Parent vote more than non-parents. Most sup court justices are parents.
There's probably legal precedent to overturn, but this is a matter of moral panic
Other branches can delegate authority under certain situations and they won't want to set a precedent undermining this

Updating my forecast because I realized that J. Kavanaugh won't even be part of the decision. So once I remove him from the numbers, it's even less likely that the case will go against the United States.

In my other Supreme Court forecasts, I did a standard, "Well he's said this in the past...and at oral arguments, she said this" analysis. For this one, I want to try out a totally different approach that starts with identifying a Justice who seems clearly in favor of deciding one way. In this case, I chose J. Gorsuch because of the things he said during oral arguments . Then, based on the percentages of which Justices vote with him the most, I come up with a starting number. In this case, J. Thomas (84%); J. Alito (84%); CJ. Roberts (81%). I don't have good numbers for J. Kavanaugh, so just for fun, let's make him a slightly more conservative J. Kennedy at 86% (J. Kennedy was 82%). So J. Gorsuch votes with this group 83.75% of the time. Leads to a 5-4 decision that has happened 12% of the time in the current session...so 10%-ish. I'm not taking into consideration any other factors. And I haven't taken a math class in literally decades, so if you see an obvious flaw, feel free to tell me. I'm here to learn.
The decision will keep the doctrine on life support, but little more.
There may be a good case out there regarding nondelegstion, but this isn't it.  AGs also need confirmation, qed.

Unsympathetic individual makes hair-splitting argument seeking exclusion from a class that is managed and controlled under legislation passed after his offense. There is a legislative solution for this. I'm surprised the SC even agreed to hear this one.

Oral argument analysis points to a win for the government. Also, this noob will now & forever hedge toward the "NO" after getting burned by the Weyerhauser (tree frog) opinion. The Roberts' Court has often issued narrow opinions, which in the future may not even consider the question stated in this Challenge. Warning! "NO" is drastically more likely when there is even a hint of a narrow opinion. I may be proven sort of right, the habitat may not be set aside for the froggies, but scotus declined to answer the question. OUCH!
After reading the oral arguments, I only see Justice Gorsuch on the side the Petitioner.

The legislative branch routinely writes laws and then hands over the details (writing details, administering details, fines, taking people to court) to the executive branch.  Been this way for a long time.
The court won't interject itself here.

It's unlikely that the delegation will be overturned because it's been common practice for so long. The Court would need some clear reasons for negating the practice. On the other hand, I do agree that Congress has delegated too many of its responsibilities.

On the court’s second day, the justices heard arguments in Gundy v. United States. The case involves whether mandatory registration as a sex offender may be imposed retroactively.
The legal issue concerns whether the Constitution allows Congress to empower the U.S. attorney general to act retroactively without explicit guidance on use of that power.
It has been 83 years (1935) since the Court voided a government action on the basis of the nondelegation doctrine.
making law as one goes in not the way to do business

Test 11. It seems all Justices favor the criminal defendant in oral arguments. Somehow the Court will rule to disallow retroactive punishment. Not sure it will be as clear cut as the question above. But, has to be closer to yes than no.

This one is bizarre.  Because this is a splitless issue, the cert grant usually means at least four were predisposed towards R, but from oral argument the only one who seemed to remain that way was Gorsuch.  I'd suspect Thomas, but his vote in Reynolds suggests the opposite. This feels to me similar to Oil States from last year; a surprising splitless separation-of-powers cert grant where the biggest question after the decision comes out winds up being "who in the world were the four to grant cert"? Gorsuch is lock R, Alito lock A.  Kagan and Breyer are solid A.  I'd say Sotomayor leans A, and the rest are toss-ups, all fairly independently so.  That means R depends on every toss-up going that way, plus a lean.  The splitless grant gives me pause, but it's very hard to count to 5 for R here, so I'll go with 10%.  Might change if it takes a while to decide.

The nondelegation doctrine makes its return to the U.S. Supreme Court this term with Gundy v. United States, scheduled to be argued on October 2, 2018. The case involves whether the Constitution allows Congress to empower the U.S. attorney general to apply the Sex Offender Notification and Registration Act (SORNA) retroactively (as was done to defendant Herman Gundy) without providing guidance about how to use that power. Not since 1935 has the Court ruled that a congressional action was unconstitutional on nondelegation grounds. Pacific Legal Foundation attorney Mark Miller wrote in The Hill that ‘’our Founding Fathers delegated the lawmaking authority to Congress, and then made legislators responsible to the people by allowing the people to vote them in or out of office every two years, according to how Congress abused or properly used its lawmaking power. Congress insulates itself from this accountability by shirking its lawmaking responsibility and handing it off to bureaucrats. The Supreme Court should use the Gundy case to put a stop to this purposeful avoidance of accountability.” Courts writer for Slate Mark Joseph Stern said many “progressives fear that, once resuscitated, the [nondelegation doctrine] could be used to strike down all manner of economic regulations [...] These days, Congress hands off most regulatory authority to a slew of federal agencies situated in the executive branch. A court concerned about nondelegation could strike down a vast range of liberal legislation under the doctrine. Labor laws and environmental protections would be especially vulnerable, since Congress gives agencies a broad mandate to interpret and implement these measures. If the Supreme Court renders that mandate unconstitutional, federal rules that protect workers’ rights, collective bargaining, clean air, and endangered species would fall.” The Cato Institute argued in its amicus brief that, “The Vesting Clauses in the Constitution’s first three articles establish a tripartite government of divided authority. While these may overlap at the margins, each branch retains a core set of powers such that it may check and balance the others. To permit delegation from one to another—for purported efficiency gains—undermines that original design. After all, why should Congress deliberate, make judgments, and stand accountable for each determination when it can license the executive to apply purportedly greater wisdom or technocratic expertise?”
Before hearing oral argument, I think a Yes would be supported by the originalists and one of them is about to be confirmed.
The Court should rule that it does violate that it is an unlawful delegation, but they won't.
Year almost over court dudes are old and the wax of the ear is in the system
Would be an interesting precedent. With a grain of salt, some believe it will be 8-1 affirm: https://fantasyscotus.lexpredict.com/case-prediction/gundy-v-united-states/

In the Home of the Brave we are always looking for some category of people to be afraid of so we can adopt pointless and expensive measures to make ourselves feel safer from them.  These are never repealed or modified when a successor Fear Factor is anointed, irrespective of how thoroughly their uselessness has been documented.  In my memory, we started with communists, then moved on to drug dealers, then sex offenders, and now terrorists.  Nobody but nobody, including the Honourable Justices, will do anything to make life easier for anybody in any of these categories.
